docs.lead_paragraph: Asa Hoffman, a World Chess Federation master and New York City resident, is being featured in a commercial and print advertising campaign for HIP, the health insurance company. Hoffman, a fixture on the New York City chess scene for decades, said that he got the job through his wife, Eva Veronica Hoffman, an actress. The print ad appeared most recently in Tuesday's New York Post on page 19, although Hoffman is identified as "Mooney, Jim" in the ad.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:23 a.m. | Chastened and contrite, Gov. Eliot Spitzer acknowledged this morning that he had misjudged public sentiment in proposing to grant driver's licenses to illegal immigrants, but he vowed to press Washington for comprehensive immigration legislation and said his critics had stoked partisan and irresponsible fears of immigrants. (The full text of the governor's remarks is below.)
docs.abstract: Governor Spitzer, sounding contrite and chastened, acknowledged that he had underestimated the depth of public opposition but vowed to press for comprehensive federal immigration reform.
docs.snippet: Governor Spitzer, sounding contrite and chastened, acknowledged that he had underestimated the depth of public opposition but vowed to press for comprehensive federal immigration reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: Death rates for 13 diseases that can be prevented by childhood vaccinations are at all-time lows in the United States, according to a study released Tuesday.

headline.main: Sharp Drop Seen in Deaths From Ills Fought by Vaccine

docs.lead_paragraph: John Edwards has been promising for months that if he wins the presidency, unless Congress passes a universal health care plan, he would strip all of its members of their own health care.

headline.main: Edwards Takes On Congress in New Ad

docs.abstract: "If you don't pass universal health care by July of 2009, in six months, I'm going to use my power as president to take your health care away from you," John Edwards tells Congress in an ad airing in Iowa.
docs.snippet: "If you don't pass universal health care by July of 2009, in six months, I'm going to use my power as president to take your health care away from you," John Edwards tells Congress in an ad airing in Iowa.
